review: I did not have a previous Apple TV, but with the update it received this year I was intrigued enough (and $100 seemed reasonably low enough) to give it a shot.I like it quite a bit. I have liked it enough that I bought one for a relative whom I thought would enjoy it.I like being able to have all TV shows and movies purchased on my computer's iTunes immediately available to watch on my main entertainment system. I think in the past the Apple TV had a storage capacity but as far as I can tell this doesn't so much store things as instantly retrieve them from the iTunes store as soon as you ask for it.I have iTunes match so that means all my music, even stuff I didn't purchase from iTunes, is easily accessible to listen to through my main entertainment system.I like the AirPlay functionality with my iPhone.I use the Netflix and Youtube apps a lot, those are great. I use Pandora and Vimeo sometimes. I have experimented with the radio app which is interesting but haven't used it much.As other reviewers have noted, I would have liked to have the ability to add apps over time, and/or get things like Hulu Plus, which the Roku has. But, the smoothness of the presentation and easy integration with my existing iTunes stuff is pure Apple.UPDATE 9/5/12: As you probably know, the Apple TV has Hulu Plus now. That is a great addition! The only other thing that would be extra great would be Amazon Prime Video but I doubt that will happen due to direct competition between Apple and Amazon. I did hear that the iPad has some kind of Amazon Prime app, though, so you never know.I am continuing to use the Apple TV about 50% of the time that I have my main TV on now. I still have cable and will DVR network and cable shows that I want to watch as they are broadcast. I find the interface and remote for Apple TV more pleasing than that for my cable box. I use Netflix and Hulu Plus fairly often. I am using YouTube, with its channels and subscriptions a lot more than I ever thought I would.
author: Brian K.

review: We love the integration but there really are no apps for this. It is all about buying from iTunes and that is about it. I also have a Roku and if it is apps and media streaming you are after it is the better choice.Don't get me wrong, linking into you iCloud is awesome and being able to access iTunes is too. I just miss my HBO go and Amazon Prime on this TV now that the Roku is in a different room.PopPop was in town and we were able to pull up our iPhone pics as soon as we got home. That was really cool. No one had to hover over a phone or wait for them to be transferred to a laptop or PC.

author: A A KUMAR

review: As a self proclaimed Apple fan boy who owns iPhone, iPad, & Mac I am torn for which direction to go for this review. On one hand, it is nice to push all my music and pictures form my iDevices to my TV, however the time it takes to push any videos is way too long. Renting movies from iTunes on Apple TV is nice and the ability to stream Netflix is legit. Bottom line is I hardly use the Apple TV so I feel like it wasn't worth the money. But if you play a lot of music, which seems to be what it is best at, then it'll be worth the $100.
author: Joshua Crawford

review: I love the apple tv, it pairs seamlessly with other apple devices, such as the iPad, iPhone, and iPad and the iTunes accounts. It does not have the wide selection of apps that my Roku player offers (such as amazon prime movies) however it is very user friendly and the overall navigation is extremely simple. I have one for my main tv, and I also bought one for my not so computer savy parents that are mainly enjoying Netflix on theirs, they have a hard time doing much else on it since they do not own other apple devices.
